chunks.title: Section 499 IPC - Defamation
chunks.content: Whoever, by words either spoken or intended to be read, or by signs or visible representations, makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said to defame that person.

chunks.title: Nature of Offence
chunks.content: The offence under Section 499 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.
chunks.summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.

chunks.title: Bailability
chunks.content: Section 499 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

chunks.title: Trial Jurisdiction
chunks.content: Due to seriousness, Section 499 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

chunks.title: Witness Testimony
chunks.content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.
chunks.summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.

chunks.title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
chunks.content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause of death, or identity of accused.
chunks.summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.

chunks.title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
chunks.content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) together to establish liability.
chunks.summary: Both mental and physical elements required.

chunks.case_name: Subramanian Swamy v. Union of India
chunks.ratio: Right to reputation part of Article 21.

chunks.facts: Actress made public statements on morality.
chunks.ratio: Only specific harm to reputation counts.

chunks.question: What is the punishment under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Punishment includes imprisonment and/or fine as provided by law.

chunks.question: Is Section 499 a bailable offence?
chunks.answer: No, it is generally non-bailable.

chunks.question: Is Section 499 a cognizable offence?
chunks.answer: Yes, police may register FIR and investigate without magistrate approval.

chunks.question: What is defamation according to Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Defamation is making or publishing a false statement about someone, intending to harm their reputation.

chunks.question: Is truth a defence to defamation under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Truth is a defence if the statement is made for public good.

chunks.question: Can opinions constitute defamation under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Opinions may be defamatory if they are presented as facts and harm reputation.

chunks.question: What is the maximum punishment for defamation under Section 500 IPC?
chunks.answer: Maximum punishment is two years’ imprisonment, or fine, or both.

chunks.question: Is Section 499 IPC compoundable?
chunks.answer: Yes, defamation is compoundable with court’s permission.

chunks.question: Is defamation under Section 499 IPC triable by Magistrate?
chunks.answer: Yes, usually tried by Magistrate courts.

chunks.question: Can group or companies file a defamation case under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, companies and groups can file defamation cases if their reputation is harmed.

chunks.question: Is intention required for conviction under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, intention to harm reputation is an essential element.

chunks.question: Can a juvenile be prosecuted under Section 499 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, but proceedings will be under the Juvenile Justice Act.

chunks.question: Can a conviction for defamation under Section 499 IPC be appealed?
chunks.answer: Yes, any conviction can be appealed in higher courts.

chunks.question: Does conviction under Section 499 IPC affect government employment?
chunks.answer: Yes, conviction may affect eligibility for government service.

chunks.question: What are some common defences against defamation charges?
chunks.answer: Truth, fair comment, privilege, and absence of malice are common defences.

chunks.question: Is there any limitation period for filing a defamation case?
chunks.answer: Generally, limitation period is three years from the date of offence.

chunks.question: Is medical evidence required in defamation cases?
chunks.answer: No, medical evidence is usually not needed unless physical harm is also alleged.

chunks.question: Can abetment of defamation be punished under IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, abetment is punishable under Section 107/108 IPC.

chunks.question: Can apology prevent conviction in defamation cases?
chunks.answer: Tendering an apology may mitigate punishment but does not always prevent conviction.

chunks.question: What are recent trends in defamation cases under IPC?
chunks.answer: Increased focus on online/social media defamation and balancing freedom of speech with reputational rights.
